headline: Some Stock Prices Delayed as Glitch Hits NYSE-Run Data Feed
summary: A key stock-market data feed run by the New York Stock Exchange suffered a technical glitch on Monday, leading to delays in releasing the end-of-day values of the Dow Jones Industrial Average and the S&P 500.

headline: Trucker Celadon Hires Former Swift Transportation CEO to Assist With Turnaround Efforts
summary: Celadon said Monday the company has engaged DPX Consulting LLC to oversee its main trucking unit, Celadon Trucking Services Inc., with DPX founder Richard Stocking serving as the division’s chief transformation officer.

headline: Dayton Gunman’s Friend Bought Body Armor, Authorities Allege
summary: Federal prosecutors in Ohio charged a friend of Connor Betts, the gunman who killed nine people in the Dayton, Ohio, mass shooting, with lying on federal firearms forms.

headline: New York City Considers Lifting Hostel Ban
summary: New York City could legalize hostels under a bill set to be introduced this week in the city council, the second attempt to reauthorize the budget hotels after a state law made them illegal.

headline: Trump Confirms Missile Exploded During Testing in Russia
summary: President Trump on Monday appeared to confirm reports that an advanced nuclear cruise missile had exploded during testing in Russia, saying on Monday night that the U.S. was “learning much” from the incident.

headline: PepsiCo Executive to Become UPS Finance Chief
summary: Brian Newman, currently executive vice president for finance and operations in Latin America for the beverage maker, will become UPS’s CFO on Sept. 16.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications the edition of Aug. 13, 2019

headline: State Tax Collectors Want You
summary: Theruling has unleashed a revenue grab on small business.

headline: The New Birthers
summary: If Trump’s enemies can prove he’s a ‘racist,’ he has to go away and never come back. Right?

headline: Vladimir Putin’s Chernobyl
summary: A mysterious explosion may be evidence of a new nuclear missile.

headline: Mitch McConnell’s Twitter Jailbreak
summary: Social sites may not want speech regulation, but this is how to get it.

headline: Trump Is Right—the Fed Is Still Tightening
summary: Sure, the size of the balance sheet is holding steady, but leaving riskier assets in the market will slow growth.

headline: The Rest of the Economic Story
summary: You’ve read about the rosy statistics. To make them real, check out the want ads in the local pennysaver.

headline: Eye Patch Becomes a Symbol of Freedom in Hong Kong
summary: A young woman suffers a gruesome injury as police violence escalates.

headline: A Peaceful Death, Far From Home
summary: My grandmother’s kids came to America for a better life. She followed them here.

headline: Guns and the Do-Something Fallacy
summary: An honest debate on mass shootings starts by admitting limits to federal solutions.

headline: Are We All Unilateralists Now?
summary: On war, trade and climate, Democrats sound remarkably similar to Trump.

headline: ‘Stop Mugging Grandma’ Review: Defying the Boomer Bashers
summary: Attacks on baby boomers by the younger generation imply that some earlier cohort did things better. History suggests otherwise.

headline: Freight Broker C.H. Robinson Names New CFO Amid Industry Headwinds
summary: The move comes as the Eden Prairie, Minn.-based company, the largest broker of freight services in North America, contends with softening transportation demand after last year’s red-hot freight market.

headline: Verizon to Sell Tumblr to WordPress.com Owner
summary: Verizon has agreed to sell its blogging website Tumblr to the owner of popular online-publishing tool WordPress.com, unloading for a nominal amount a site that once fetched a purchase price of more than $1 billion.

headline: Newark Distributes Bottled Water After Lead Contamination Found
summary: The city of Newark, N.J., began distributing bottled water to some residents after officials warned some city-issued water filters may not be working to sufficiently reduce lead levels.

headline: Harris Looks to Make Inroads in Iowa After Slow Start
summary: After a slow start in Iowa, Sen. Kamala Harris’s campaign is ramping up its presence and its message against President Trump, but still lags organizationally behind much more established candidates. Ms. Harris made 17 stops across 11 counties in five days during a bus tour of the state.

headline: Former NYU Standout, New to Wall Street, Charged With Insider Trading
summary: A new arrival to Wall Street and former student-body president at NYU’s Stern School of Business was charged with insider trading tied to a $1.7 billion buyout.

headline: Corn, Wheat Prices Fall on USDA Report
summary: The USDA estimated in a monthly report that 90 million acres of corn were planted by farmers this year—greater than market expectations, traders said.

headline: New Data Show Few New York Teachers of Color in the Pipeline
summary: New York school districts have long sought to diversify their teaching ranks, which are mostly white overall, to better reflect the backgrounds of their students. A new study highlights the difficulty of making headway.

headline: Trump Administration Eases Endangered Species Act Protections
summary: The Trump administration is easing several Endangered Species Act regulations, responding to complaints from developers and other business interests who say the landmark 1973 law has become too onerous.

headline: Companies Appear to Avoid Hiring Auditors With a History of Critical Audits, Research Shows
summary: There is a paradox in auditing, new research indicates: Audit firms that do a thorough job examining clients’ financial statements could be doing so at their own peril.

headline: U.S. Stocks Decline Amid Trade Woes
summary: U.S. stocks fell as a wave of selling that analysts attributed to mounting doubts about a trade deal pulled lower everything from bank stocks to shares of technology companies.

headline: Barrick Weighs New Investors in South American Gold Ventures
summary: Barrick Gold is in discussions with a variety of international investors to expand exploration and production at a pair of South America gold properties it had planned to sell last year.

headline: Bank Stocks Are Having a Rough August
summary: Falling interest rates, fears of a global economic slowdown and unrest in the Asian financial hub of Hong Kong have conspired to beat up bank stocks this month.

headline: DNA Data Shared in Ways Patients May Find Surprising
summary: Deals between drugmakers and hospital systems to mine the genetic profiles of hospital patients are triggering concerns over the control of valuable genetic data.

headline: ‘i,i’ by Bon Iver Review: A Sonic Masterpiece Woven From Past and Present
summary: On the group’s new album, the tech-heavy sound of their recent work meets the crashing orchestral folk-rock of their earlier efforts.

headline: U.S. Probing Whether Friendly Fire Killed Marine in Iraq
summary: The U.S. military is investigating whether friendly fire caused the first combat death in Iraq since U.S. troops returned there in 2014 to battle Islamic State, defense officials said.

headline: Cashierless Stores Make Inroads in U.S.
summary: U.S. retailers large and small are pressing ahead with testing the use of artificial intelligence to track what products shoppers pick up and automatically bill them when they walk out the door, eliminating the need for a checkout line.

headline: Why FedEx Dumped Amazon
summary: FedEx last week said it would stop shipping packages for Amazon. Paul Ziobro and Dana Mattioli talk about why FedEx essentially cut ties with a company that would seem to be its perfect customer.

headline: Volatility Isn’t Just for Stocks Anymore
summary: Stock-market volatility may be on its way down, but swings across other asset classes are mounting.

headline: These Are the Winners From Last Week’s Market Mayhem
summary: In addition to selling stocks and picking up assets considered safer, such as government bonds, investors are piling into funds meant to protect against stock swings.

headline: Rite Aid Names New CEO
summary: Rite Aid appointed Heyward Donigan as chief executive, saying her experience leading health-care companies would help the pharmacy chain confront competition that has hurt sales and prompted job cuts.

headline: Bain Capital Ventures Partner Salil Deshpande to Launch His Own Seed Fund
summary: Mr. Deshpande is working to establish a new venture-capital firm to invest in seed-stage software and cryptocurrency startups. He aims to raise $100 million for the new fund, the name of which hasn’t yet been determined, a person familiar with the situation said. Up to 20% of the new fund’s investments would go into crypto startups, the person added.

headline: Cloudera Not Quite a Bargain for Icahn
summary: Carl Icahn got what he wanted rather quickly at Cloudera. But the wily financier still has a lot of work ahead to mine silver from this cloud.

headline: Stocks and Bonds Are Talking Past Each Other
summary: The yawning gap between markets is perplexing some investors, who say they struggle to discern how stocks can churn higher when bond yields are signaling a downturn may not be far off.

headline: Yum Taps Company Veteran as Next CEO
summary: The next leader of KFC and Pizza Hut plans to open more restaurants and expand delivery.

headline: U.S. Government Bond Yields Slide
summary: A rally in U.S. government bonds resumed, pushing yields back to multiyear lows, as global political uncertainty further stoked investors’ economic anxieties.

headline: It’s Hard to Red Flag Only Potential Killers
summary: Nothing will get done without bipartisan support for meaningful ideas to combat gun violence.

headline: China Is No Manipulator
summary: We cannot on one hand condemn China for manipulating currency and then turn around and do the same.

headline: California Curriculum Proposal Is in Process
summary: California is developing an Ethnic Studies Model Curriculum in response to a 2016 state law. The draft recently posted, which Mr. Evers critiqued as if it was already adopted, is many months away from coming to the state board for review or approval.

headline: Check for Dallas Mansion Raises New Questions About NRA Plans
summary: A $70,000 payment from the NRA to a company created by its then-outside advertising agency raises new questions about the NRA’s explanations about an aborted plan to buy a $6 million Dallas mansion for CEO Wayne LaPierre.

headline: New York Public Library’s Lions to Get Facelift
summary: The New York Public Library’s famed marble lions, which have long guarded the entrance to the library’s main branch, are about to undergo restoration.

headline: Hackers Go Pro, Seeking Bounties for Bugs
summary: The market for pointing out flaws in software has become more structured: Companies are willing to shell out huge sums to researchers who find zero-day vulnerabilities, or those that are totally unknown to developers.

headline: A Film Noir Icon Turns 75
summary: Billy Wilder’s ‘Double Indemnity,’ released in 1944, was the first fully developed example of the genre.

headline: Gov. Cuomo Signs Tougher Workplace Harassment Law
summary: Gov. Andrew Cuomo changed the legal standard for workplace harassment claims in New York, a move that advocates said was long overdue and could result in more litigation against employers.

headline: New Beginnings for New Music
summary: Tanglewood introduced a new venue, a new learning institute and several premieres at this year’s annual Festival of Contemporary Music.

headline: Bolton Says U.S. Strongly Backs Brexit Even if No EU Deal Is Reached
summary: President Trump’s national security adviser said he told Britain’s prime minister that the administration would strongly back the U.K.’s exit from the EU in late October—deal or no deal.

headline: ‘Geek and Gamer’ Subscription Service Loot Crate Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Loot Crate, a “geek and gamer” subscription business whose backers include actor Robert Downey Jr.’s venture-capital firm, has filed for bankruptcy, saying it needs protection from creditors to complete millions of dollars in customer orders.

headline: Two Experimental Ebola Drugs Reduce Mortality Rate, According to Preliminary Data
summary: Two experimental Ebola drugs significantly improve a patient’s chance of surviving the virus, according to preliminary data from a medical trial, offering fresh hope for stopping an outbreak of the disease in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

headline: U.S. Budget Gap Widens 27% in First 10 Months of Fiscal Year
summary: The U.S. budget gap widened further in July as federal spending outpaced revenue collection, bringing the deficit to $867 billion so far this fiscal year, a 27% increase from the same period a year earlier.

headline: Aramco Bulks Up on Refining With $15 Billion Deal
summary: Saudi Aramco is buying a stake in Reliance’s energy business, worth some $15 billion including debt, a move that would help match its enormous crude production with refining capacity, as it gears up for its planned IPO.

headline: Schools Fight Websites That Sell Homework Help
summary: As the school year starts off, colleges and high schools are increasing steps to spot and fight a persistent form of cheating in which students find someone online to do their homework.

headline: CBS, Viacom in Final Stages of Deal Talks
summary: CBS and Viacom are in the final stages of negotiating a deal that would reunite mogul Sumner Redstone’s media empire in the hopes of creating a more formidable competitor to the entertainment industry’s giants.

headline: Salvini’s Promises Raise New Questions for Italian Economy
summary: The next Italian government is likely to be led by Matteo Salvini, whose apparent willingness to run bigger budget deficits raises the risk of a clash with the EU and a rocky period for markets.

headline: A Paper Twist in the War on Plastic
summary: Paper-packaging companies like Mondi are well placed to benefit from a backlash against plastic as well as growth in e-commerce.

headline: Olive Garden Pushes the Limits of Free Food
summary: The company’s Lifetime Pasta Pass is a great marketing stunt, but a  potentially costly one in the wrong hands.

headline: India Enforces Tight Security in Kashmir
summary: Residents of the disputed area observe Muslim holiday of Eid al-Adha amid a clampdown that closed the capital city’s key mosques.

headline: Think U.S. Politics Is Exhausting? Mexico’s President Has a News Conference Every Morning.
summary: In his one-man show at 7 a.m. sharp, Andrés Manuel López Obrador fields softball questions and talks…and talks…and talks.

headline: Sanchez Energy Files for Bankruptcy, Casualty of Commodity Price Volatility
summary: Sanchez Energy Corp. filed for bankruptcy protection after struggling with slumping energy prices, volatile markets and a dispute with Blackstone Group.

headline: The Unlikely Survival of USA Gymnastics
summary: In the wake of the Nassar scandal, USA Gymnastics is still standing—and imagining a future.

headline: Malibu Manse in Exclusive Gated Community Lists for $100 Million
summary: Scott Gillen, the developer behind the 12,500-square-foot home, is looking to capitalize on buzz surrounding several record-breaking deals.

headline: Stocks to Watch: GE, Sysco, AMD, BlackRock, CBS, Rite Aid and More
summary: Shares of General Electric, Sysco, Advanced Micro Devices, BlackRock, CBS and Rite Aid are among the stocks expected to trade actively in Monday’s session.

headline: Trump’s Primary Advantage: No Real Competition
summary: President Trump is an incumbent who apparently won’t face a significant challenge from within his own party, a powerful edge as he seeks re-election.

headline: Aramco Profit Hurt by Oil Prices
summary: Saudi Aramco said net income fell in the first half of the year because of lower oil prices, but the oil giant still reported the biggest profit of any reporting company and said it was ready for an initial public offering that its shareholder, the kingdom of Saudi Arabia, has been planning for years.

headline: Argentina’s President Suffers Setback in Primary
summary: Argentina’s pro-business President Mauricio Macri suffered a crushing setback in a primary election that indicated he might be voted out of office in October and see his market overhauls undone.

headline: Fed Considers New Tool for a Downturn
summary: Federal Reserve officials are weighing whether to use a tool known as the countercyclical capital buffer, which could reduce the risk of a credit crunch in a downturn.

headline: Simone Biles Tests the Boundaries of Gymnastics
summary: Simone Biles landed a record-busting triple-twisting double somersault on Sunday night to take a sixth national title.

headline: Minneapolis’s North Loop Is Filled With Cutting-Edge Design
summary: The North Loop neighborhood, the Midwestern city’s former warehouse district, is replete with boutique hotels, chic cafes and independent shops.

headline: Brené Brown Saves These Texts From Her Sisters
summary: The professor and best-selling motivational speaker, whose viral TED talks paved the way for her ‘Brené Brown: The Call to Courage’ Netflix special, talks about what’s on her iPhone

headline: Chinese Financial Institutions’ Lending Dives
summary: Lending by Chinese financial institutions slumped in July on weakening demand, signaling further economic headwinds from trade tensions with the U.S. and potentially paving the way for more stimulus efforts by Beijing’s policy makers.

headline: 2020 Democrats Get a Fair Hearing in Iowa
summary: Stump speeches—and the crowds they drew—at Iowa’s state fair provide an unscientific indicator of Democratic presidential candidates’ support among potential caucus-goers.

headline: BlackRock Fund’s First Big Private-Equity Deal Is a Sign of What’s to Come
summary: BlackRock’s private-equity fund hopes its deal for a stake in Authentic Brands will be the first in a series that will help the firm close the gap with private-equity rivals, and drive momentum for a fund designed to hold stakes for the long haul.

headline: Hurry Up! Sports Has a Time Problem
summary: Golfers take ages to line up shots. Baseball games last longer than ”Godfather” movies. It’s time to pick up the pace, writes Jason Gay.

headline: Hong Kong’s Main Airline Warns Staff Over Protest Links
summary: The threat to Cathay Pacific’s employees comes as Hong Kong’s airport canceled the day’s remaining flights after thousands of protesters flooded the main terminal.

headline: KKR to Acquire 70% Stake in China’s NVC Lighting Holding
summary: KKR has agreed to acquire a 70% stake in China’s NVC Lighting Holding, valuing the company at $794 million.

headline: Delivery Guys Take a Bite Out of Domino’s
summary: Domino’s could get served in its commitment to serving its own food.

headline: South Korea Kicks Japan Off List of Favored Trading Partners
summary: South Korea said it would remove Japan from a list of countries that qualify for accelerated imports of its products, a move signaled earlier this month when Tokyo enacted a similar measure against South Korea.

headline: Trump’s Threats to Devalue the Dollar Aren’t Credible
summary: U.S. policy makers don’t currently have the tools necessary to weaken the greenback.

headline: Protesters Fill Hong Kong Airport
summary: Hong Kong’s airport authority canceled more than 100 flights as demonstrators converged after a night of violence to protest authorities for their handling of this summer’s unrest.

headline: Tencent Earnings: What to Watch
summary: Chinese tech giant Tencent is scheduled to report its second-quarter earnings after the market closes in Hong Kong on Wednesday. Here’s what you need to know.

headline: China Says Hong Kong Protests Show ‘First Signs of Terrorism’
summary: Chinese authorities condemned violent weekend demonstrations in Hong Kong as “deranged acts” that marked the emergence of “the first signs of terrorism” in the semiautonomous city, vowing a merciless crackdown on the perpetrators.

headline: Hong Kong Cancels More Flights After Protests Hit Airport
summary: Thousands of passengers remain stranded in Hong Kong for a second straight day, as hundreds of flights were canceled after antigovernment demonstrators occupied the airport.

headline: U.S. to Deny Green Cards to Legal Immigrants Who Use Public Aid
summary: The Trump administration issued a rule that would disqualify legal immigrants from permanent residency if they use certain public-assistance programs, a move that immigration advocates said punishes poor migrants.

headline: Barr Cites ‘Serious Irregularities’ at Federal Jail Where Epstein Died
summary: Investigators probing the apparent suicide of Jeffrey Epstein have found “serious irregularities” at the federal jail in New York where the disgraced financier was being held on sex-trafficking charges, Attorney General William Barr said.

headline: Argentine Peso Dives on Concerns About Peronists’ Potential Return
summary: Argentina’s peso had its worst fall in at least a decade amid investor concerns about the potential return to power of the country’s populist Peronist movement.

headline: Airlines Forced to Cancel, Reroute Flights After Hong Kong Shutdown
summary: International airlines set about trying to reschedule flights for throngs of passengers caught in the political turmoil engulfing Hong Kong after authorities shut down the city’s airport, one of the world’s busiest hubs.

headline: Energy & Utilities Roundup: Market Talk
summary: The latest Market Talks covering Energy and Utilities

headline: An Investigation Into the Death of Dag Hammarskjöld Goes Gonzo
summary: Mads Brügger’s sardonic approach to a serious subject won over the Sundance Film Festival. Now he’s asking U.S. audiences to revisit this cold case.

headline: Just How Important Is a Presidential Candidate’s Hair?
summary: Donald Trump’s comb-over has become the president’s sartorial signature. Can any of the Democratic presidential candidates compete when it comes to memorable hairdos?

headline: 10% Tariffs Were Manageable. At 25%, Businesses Are Squirming.
summary: An importer of vinyl flooring spends “nearly 100% of my energy” trying to defray the cost of Washington’s levies on Chinese products. How these decisions get made, across the economy, will help determine how higher costs get distributed and their effects on sales.

headline: Yes, You Can Kondo Your Refrigerator
summary: Color-coordinated food lineups and pristine shelves are wowing house guests, baffling family members and inspiring boasts on social media.

headline: GM, Volkswagen Say Goodbye to Hybrid Vehicles
summary: Two of the world’s largest auto makers say they see no future for hybrid vehicles in their U.S. lineups. Their view contrasts with Toyota and Ford, which are working on full electrics but also expanding their U.S. hybrid offerings.

headline: Are You Agile Enough for Agile Management?
summary: Agile management—an up-tempo approach to projects—might be coming soon to a conference room near you. Applied wisely, it can enhance teamwork and productivity. But it might also risk career damage for people who are reticent or lacking in confidence.

headline: Wealth of Jeffrey Epstein’s Brother Is Also a Mystery
summary: The wealth held by Mark Epstein, brother of Jeffrey Epstein, appears to be tiny by comparison to that of the late financier, but also hard to assess.

headline: EU Nears Decisions in Facebook Privacy Cases
summary: The EU could begin to hit Facebook with decisions under the bloc’s new privacy law by the end of the year, raising the specter of billions of euros in fines and orders to change business practices.
